Metric Spaces!

Distance: Let UUU be a normed linear space. For u,v∈Uu,v\in Uu,v∈U, we define the distance between uuu and vvv to be

d(u,v)=∥v−u∥d(u,v)=\|v-u\| d(u,v)=∥v−u∥

Theorem 4.17: Let UUU be a normed linear space. For all u,v,w∈Uu,v,w\in Uu,v,w∈U,

  1. Symmetry: d(u,v)=d(v,u)d(u,v)=d(v,u)d(u,v)=d(v,u)
  2. Positive Definiteness: d(u,v)≥0d(u,v)\ge 0d(u,v)≥0 with d(u,v)=0d(u,v)=0d(u,v)=0 if and only if u=vu=vu=v
  3. Triangle Inequality: d(u,w)≤d(u,v)+d(v,w)d(u,w)\le d(u,v) + d(v,w)d(u,w)≤d(u,v)+d(v,w)

Metric: Let XXX be a set. A metric on XXX is a map d:X×X→Rd:X\times X \rightarrow \mathbb{R}d:X×X→R such that for all a,b,c∈Xa,b,c\in Xa,b,c∈X, we have

  1. Symmetry: d(a,b)=d(b,a)d(a,b)=d(b,a)d(a,b)=d(b,a)
  2. Positive Definiteness: d(a,b)≥0d(a,b)\ge 0d(a,b)≥0 with d(a,b)=0d(a,b)=0d(a,b)=0 if and only if a=ba=ba=b
  3. Triangle Inequality: d(a,c)≤d(a,b)+d(b,c)d(a,c)\le d(a,b) + d(b,c)d(a,c)≤d(a,b)+d(b,c)

For a,b∈Xa,b\in Xa,b∈X, d(a,b)d(a,b)d(a,b) is called the distance between aaa and bbb. A metric space is a set XXX which is equipped with a metric ddd, and we sometimes denote the metric space by XXX and somtimes by the pair (X,d)(X,d)(X,d). Given two metric spaces (X,dX)(X,d_X)(X,dX​) and (Y,dY)(Y,d_Y)(Y,dY​), a map f:X→Yf:X\rightarrow Yf:X→Y is called a homomorphism of a metric spaces, or wesay that fff is distance preserving when dY(f(a),f(b))=dX(a,b)d_Y(f(a), f(b))=d_X(a,b)dY​(f(a),f(b))=dX​(a,b) for all a,b∈Xa,b\in Xa,b∈X. A bijective homomorphism is called an isomorphism or an isometry.

Note that

  • Every inner product space is also a normed linear space, using the induced norm given by ∥u∥=⟨u,u⟩\|u\|=\sqrt{\langle u,u \rangle}∥u∥=⟨u,u⟩​.
  • Every normed linear space is also a metric space, using the induced metric given by d(u,v)=∥v−u∥d(u,v)=\|v-u\|d(u,v)=∥v−u∥.
  • If UUU is an inner product space then every subspace of UUU is also an inner product space using the restriction of the same inner product used in UUU.
  • If UUU is a normed linear space then every subspace of UUU is also a normed linear space using the same norm.
  • If XXX is a metric space then so is every subset of XXX using the same metric.

Metrics for Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn:

  • 1-metric: d1(a,b)=∥a−b∥1=∑k=1n∣ak−bk∣\displaystyle d_1(a,b)=\|a-b\|_1=\sum_{k=1}^n |a_k - b_k|d1​(a,b)=∥a−b∥1​=k=1∑n​∣ak​−bk​∣
  • 2-metric aka standard metric:

    d(a,b)=d2(a,b)=∥a−b∥2=(∑k=1n∣ak−bk∣2)1/2\displaystyle d(a,b)=d_2(a,b)=\|a-b\|_2=\left( \sum_{k=1}^n |a_k-b_k|^2 \right)^{1/2} d(a,b)=d2​(a,b)=∥a−b∥2​=(k=1∑n​∣ak​−bk​∣2)1/2

  • infinity metric aka supremum metric:

    d∞(a,b)=∥a−b∥∞=max⁡{∣ak−bk∣:1≤k≤n}d_\infty(a,b)=\|a-b\|_\infty=\max\{ |a_k-b_k|:1\le k\le n\} d∞​(a,b)=∥a−b∥∞​=max{∣ak​−bk​∣:1≤k≤n}

Metrics for ℓ1\ell_1ℓ1​:

  • 1-metric: d1(a,b)=∥a−b∥1=∑k=1∞∣ak−bk∣\displaystyle d_1(a,b)=\|a-b\|_1=\sum_{k=1}^\infty |a_k - b_k|d1​(a,b)=∥a−b∥1​=k=1∑∞​∣ak​−bk​∣
  • 2-metric: d2(a,b)=∥a−b∥2=(∑k=1∞∣ak−bk∣2)1/2\displaystyle d_2(a,b)=\|a-b\|_2=\left( \sum_{k=1}^\infty |a_k-b_k|^2 \right)^{1/2}d2​(a,b)=∥a−b∥2​=(k=1∑∞​∣ak​−bk​∣2)1/2
  • infinity metric: d∞(a,b)=∥a−b∥∞=sup⁡{∣ak−bk∣:k∈Z+}d_\infty(a,b)=\|a-b\|_\infty=\sup\{ |a_k-b_k|:k\in \mathbb{Z}^+\}d∞​(a,b)=∥a−b∥∞​=sup{∣ak​−bk​∣:k∈Z+}

Note that by Theorem 4.13. we could use any of d1,d2,d∞d_1, d_2, d_\inftyd1​,d2​,d∞​ in the space R∞\mathbb{R}^\inftyR∞, and we could use d2,d∞d_2, d_\inftyd2​,d∞​ in the space ℓ2\ell_2ℓ2​.

Metrics for X⊆C[a,b]X\subseteq \mathcal{C}[a,b]X⊆C[a,b]:

  • 1-metric: d1(f,g)=∥f−g∥1=∫ab∣f(x)−g(x)∣ dx\displaystyle d_1(f,g)=\|f-g\|_1=\int_a^b |f(x)-g(x)|\ dxd1​(f,g)=∥f−g∥1​=∫ab​∣f(x)−g(x)∣ dx
  • 2-metric: d2(f,g)=∥f−g∥2=(∫ab∣f(x)−g(x)∣2)1/2\displaystyle d_2(f,g)=\|f-g\|_2=\left( \int_a^b |f(x)- g(x)|^2 \right)^{1/2}d2​(f,g)=∥f−g∥2​=(∫ab​∣f(x)−g(x)∣2)1/2

Metric for X⊆B[a,b]X\subseteq \mathcal{B}[a,b]X⊆B[a,b]:

  • infinity metric: d∞(f,g)=∥f−g∥∞=max⁡{∣f(x)−g(x)∣:x∈[a,b]}d_\infty(f,g)=\|f-g\|_\infty=\max\{ |f(x)-g(x)|: x\in[a,b]\}d∞​(f,g)=∥f−g∥∞​=max{∣f(x)−g(x)∣:x∈[a,b]}

Discrete Metric: For any nonempty set X≠∅X\neq\emptyX​=∅, the discrete metric on XXX is given by

d(x,y)={1,x≠y0,x=y,x,y∈Xd(x,y)=\begin{cases}1, &x\neq y\\ 0, & x=y\end{cases},\qquad x,y\in X d(x,y)={1,0,​x​=yx=y​,x,y∈X

There are a ridiculously vast number of metrics that one could define on R\mathbb{R}R. For example, if we let f:R→Rf:\mathbb{R}\rightarrow \mathbb{R}f:R→R be a bijective map then we can define a metric on R\mathbb{R}R by d(x,y)=∣f(x)−f(y)∣d(x,y)=|f(x)-f(y)|d(x,y)=∣f(x)−f(y)∣.

Open and Closed Sets in Metric Spaces

Balls: Let XXX be a metric. For a∈Xa\in Xa∈X and 0<r∈R0<r\in \mathbb{R}0<r∈R, the open ball, closed ball and punctured ball in XXX centred at aaa of radius rrr are defined respectively as

B(a,r)=BX(a,r)={x∈X:d(x,a)<r}B‾(a,r)=B‾X(a,r)={x∈X:d(x,a)≤r}B∗(a,r)=BX∗(a,r)={x∈X:0<d(x,a)<r}\begin{aligned} B(a,r)= B_X(a,r)&=\{x\in X:d(x,a)<r\}\\ \overline{B}(a,r) = \overline{B}_X(a,r) &= \{x\in X:d(x,a)\le r\}\\ B^*(a,r)= B_X^*(a,r)&=\{x\in X:0<d(x,a)<r\} \end{aligned}B(a,r)=BX​(a,r)B(a,r)=BX​(a,r)B∗(a,r)=BX∗​(a,r)​={x∈X:d(x,a)<r}={x∈X:d(x,a)≤r}={x∈X:0<d(x,a)<r}​

When the metric on XXX is denoted by dpd_pdp​ with 1≤p≤∞1\le p\le \infty1≤p≤∞, we often write the above as B(a,r),B‾(a,r),B∗(a,r)B(a,r), \overline{B}(a,r), B^*(a,r)B(a,r),B(a,r),B∗(a,r). For A⊆XA\subseteq XA⊆X, we say that AAA is bounded when A⊆B(a,r)A\subseteq B(a,r)A⊆B(a,r) for some a∈Xa\in Xa∈X and some 0<r∈R0<r\in \mathbb{R}0<r∈R.

Open and Closed Sets: Let XXX be a metric space. For A⊆XA\subseteq XA⊆X, we say that AAA is open in XXX when for every a∈Aa\in Aa∈A there exists r>0r>0r>0 such that B(a,r)⊆AB(a,r)\subseteq AB(a,r)⊆A, and we say that AAA is closed in XXX when its complement Ac=X\AA^c=X\backslash AAc=X\A is open in XXX.

Example 4.31: Let XXX be a metric space and let a∈Xa\in Xa∈X. Show that {a}\{a\}{a} is closed in XXX.

Solution: We shall show that {a}c=X\{a}\{a\}^c=X\backslash \{a\}{a}c=X\{a} is open. Let b∈X\{a}b\in X\backslash \{a\}b∈X\{a} and let r=d(a,b)r=d(a,b)r=d(a,b). We need to show that every B(b,r)∋x≠a⟹x∈X\{a}B(b,r)\ni x\neq a \Longrightarrow x\in X\backslash \{a\}B(b,r)∋x​=a⟹x∈X\{a}. Thus B(b,r)⊆X\{a}B(b,r)\subseteq X\backslash \{a\}B(b,r)⊆X\{a} and X\{a}X\backslash \{a\}X\{a} is open, and so {a}\{a\}{a} is closed.

Exercise 4.32: Let XXX be a metric space. Show that for a∈Xa\in Xa∈X and 0<r∈R0<r\in \mathbb{R}0<r∈R, the set B(a,r)B(a,r)B(a,r) is open and the set B‾(a,r)\overline{B}(a,r)B(a,r) is closed.

In R\mathbb{R}R, using its standard metric, an open ball is the same thing as a bounded non-degenerate open interval, and a closed ball is the same thing as a bounded non-degenerate closed interval. The unbounded open intervals (a,∞),(−∞,b)(a,\infty), (-\infty, b)(a,∞),(−∞,b) are open, and the unbounded closed intervals [a,∞),(−∞,b][a,\infty),(-\infty, b][a,∞),(−∞,b] are closed. The degenerate closed intervals [a,a]={a}[a,a]=\{a\}[a,a]={a} are closed. The degenerate intervals (a,a)=∞(a,a)=\infty(a,a)=∞ and the interval (−∞,∞)=R(-\infty, \infty)=\mathbb{R}(−∞,∞)=R are both open and closed (see Theorem 4.34). The bounded non-degenerate half-open intervals [a,b),(a,b][a,b), (a,b][a,b),(a,b] are neither open or closed.

Theorem 4.35, Basic Properties of Open Sets: Let XXX be a metric space.

  1. The sets ∅\empty∅ and XXX are open in XXX.
  2. If SSS is a set of open sets in XXX then the union ⋃U∈SU\displaystyle \bigcup_{U\in S} UU∈S⋃​U is open in XXX.
  3. If SSS is a finite set of open sets in XXX then the intersection ⋂U∈SU\displaystyle \bigcap_{U\in S} UU∈S⋂​U is open in XXX.

Proof Sketch:

  • The empty set is open because it's vacuously true. The set XXX is open because any open ball is subset of XXX.
  • To prove part 3, if S≠∅S\neq\emptyS​=∅, for every point in the intersection, choose the smallest ball of each open set, and that meets the definition of open set.

Theorem 4.36, Basic Properties of Closed Sets: Let XXX be a metric space.

  1. The sets ∅\empty∅ and XXX are closed in XXX.
  2. If SSS is a set of closed sets in XXX then the intersections ⋂K∈SK\displaystyle \bigcap_{K\in S}KK∈S⋂​K is closed in XXX.
  3. If SSS is a finite set of closed sets in XXX then the union ⋃K∈SK\displaystyle \bigcup_{K\in S} KK∈S⋃​K is closed in XXX.

Proof Hint: This follows from 4.35, by taking complements using DeMorgan's Law:

(⋃A∈SA)c=⋂A∈SAc(⋂A∈SA)c=⋃A∈SAc\left( \bigcup_{A\in S} A \right)^c=\bigcap_{A\in S}A^c\qquad \left( \bigcap_{A\in S}A \right)^c=\bigcup_{A\in S} A^c (A∈S⋃​A)c=A∈S⋂​Ac(A∈S⋂​A)c=A∈S⋃​Ac

Example 4.37: punctured ball is open by Theorem 4.35, part 2.

Example 4.38: in R\mathbb{R}R, note that ⋂n=1∞(−1n,1+1n)=[0,1]\displaystyle \bigcap_{n=1}^\infty \left( - \frac{1}{n}, 1+ \frac{1}{n} \right)=[0,1]n=1⋂∞​(−n1​,1+n1​)=[0,1] which is closed and not open, so the intersection of an infinite set of open sets is not always open. Similarly, note that ⋃n=1∞[1n,1−1n]=(0,1)\displaystyle \bigcup_{n=1}^\infty \left[ \frac{1}{n}, 1-\frac{1}{n} \right]=(0,1)n=1⋃∞​[n1​,1−n1​]=(0,1), which is open and not closed, so the union of an infinite set of closed sets is not always closed.

Topological Spaces

A topology on a set XXX is a set TTT of subsets of XXX such that

  1. ∅∈T\empty\in T∅∈T and X∈TX\in TX∈T
  2. for every set S⊆TS\subseteq TS⊆T we have ⋃S∈T\bigcup S\in T⋃S∈T
  3. for every finite subset S⊆TS\subseteq TS⊆T we have ⋂S∈T\bigcap S\in T⋂S∈T

A topological space is a set XXX with a topology TTT. When XXX is a metric space, the set of all open sets in XXX is a topology on XXX, which we call the metric topology or the topology induced by the metric.

When XXX is any topological space, the sets in the topology TTT are called the open sets in XXX and their complements are called the closed sets in XXX. When SSS and TTT are both topologies on set XXX with S⊆TS\subseteq TS⊆T, we say that the topology TTT is finer than the topology SSS, and that the topology SSS is coarser than the topology TTT. When S⊂TS\subset TS⊂T we say that TTT is strictly finer than SSS and that SSS is strictly coarser than TTT.

Example 4.40: Show that on Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn, the metrics d1,d2,d∞d_1, d_2, d_\inftyd1​,d2​,d∞​ all induce the same topology.

Solution: For a,x∈Rna,x\in \mathbb{R}^na,x∈Rn we see that

d∞(a,x)≤d2(a,x)≤d1(a,x)≤nd∞(a,x)d_\infty(a,x)\le d_2(a,x)\le d_1(a,x)\le n d_\infty(a,x) d∞​(a,x)≤d2​(a,x)≤d1​(a,x)≤nd∞​(a,x)

It follows that for all a∈Rna\in \mathbb{R}^na∈Rn and r>0r>0r>0 we have

B∞(a,r)⊇B2(a,r)⊇B1(a,r)⊇B∞(a,r/n)B_\infty(a,r)\supseteq B_2(a,r) \supseteq B_1(a,r) \supseteq B_\infty(a,r/n) B∞​(a,r)⊇B2​(a,r)⊇B1​(a,r)⊇B∞​(a,r/n)

Hence for U⊆RnU\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nU⊆Rn, if UUU is open in Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn using d∞d_\inftyd∞​ then so is d2d_2d2​. If UUU is open using d2d_2d2​ then so is d1d_1d1​. If UUU is open using d1d_1d1​ then so is d∞d_\inftyd∞​.

Example 4.41: Show that on the space C[a,b]\mathcal{C}[a,b]C[a,b], the topology induced by the metric d∞d_\inftyd∞​ is strictly finer than the topology induced by the metric d1d_1d1​.

Solution: For f,g∈C[a,b]f,g\in \mathcal{C}[a,b]f,g∈C[a,b] we have d1(f,g)≤(b−a) d∞(f,g)d_1(f,g)\le (b-a)\ d_\infty (f,g)d1​(f,g)≤(b−a) d∞​(f,g). It follows that B∞(f,r)⊆B1(f,(b−a)r)B_\infty(f,r)\subseteq B_1(f, (b-a)r)B∞​(f,r)⊆B1​(f,(b−a)r). Thus for U⊆C[a,b]U\subseteq \mathcal{C}[a,b]U⊆C[a,b], if UUU is open using d1d_1d1​ then UUU is also open using d∞d_\inftyd∞​.

To show its strictly finer, we simply need to find a counter example, in this case, a bump function would do.

For any set XXX, the trivial topology on XXX is the topology in which the only open sets are ∅\empty∅ and XXX. The discrete topology on XXX is the topology in which every subset of XXX is open. Note that the discrete metric on a nonempty set XXX induces the discrete topology on XXX.

Interior and Closure

Let XXX be the metric space or a topological space and let A⊆XA\subseteq XA⊆X. The interior and the closure of AAA in XXX are the sets

Ao=⋃{U⊆X:U is open, and U⊆A}A‾=⋂{K⊆X:K is closed, and A⊆K}\begin{aligned} A^o&=\bigcup \{ U\subseteq X : U\textrm{ is open, and }U\subseteq A\}\\ \overline{A}&=\bigcap\{K\subseteq X: K\textrm{ is closed, and } A\subseteq K\} \end{aligned}AoA​=⋃{U⊆X:U is open, and U⊆A}=⋂{K⊆X:K is closed, and A⊆K}​

Example 4.44: Show that Q‾=R\overline{\mathbb{Q}}=\mathbb{R}Q​=R.

Solution: Let S={K⊆R:K is closed in R,Q⊆K}S=\{K\subseteq \mathbb{R}: K\textrm{ is closed in }\mathbb{R}, \mathbb{Q}\subseteq K\}S={K⊆R:K is closed in R,Q⊆K} so that Q‾=⋂S\overline{\mathbb{Q}}=\bigcap SQ​=⋂S. Let a∈Ra\in \mathbb{R}a∈R, suppose for a contradiction that for some K∈SK\in SK∈S, a∉Ka\notin Ka∈/​K, then a∈Kc=R\Ka\in K^c=\mathbb{R}\backslash Ka∈Kc=R\K which is open. So there exists an open ball around aaa that's not in KKK. But this is impossible since Q\mathbb{Q}Q is dense in R\mathbb{R}R (Theorem 1.11), so there does exist x∈Qx\in \mathbb{Q}x∈Q with x∈(a−r,a+r)x\in (a-r, a+r)x∈(a−r,a+r). Thus a∈Ka\in Ka∈K as required.

Density: Let XXX be a metric space or a topological space and let A⊆XA\subseteq XA⊆X. We say that AAA is dense when A‾=X\overline{A}=XA=X.

Theorem 4.46: Let XXX be a metric space or a topological space, and let A⊆XA\subseteq XA⊆X.

  1. The interior of AAA is the largest open set which is contained in AAA. In other words, Ao⊆AA^o\subseteq AAo⊆A and AoA^oAo is open, and for every open set U⊆AU\subseteq AU⊆A we have U⊆AoU\subseteq A^oU⊆Ao.
  2. The closure of AAA is the smallest closed set which contains AAA. In other words, A⊆A‾A\subseteq \overline{A}A⊆A and A‾\overline{A}A is closed, and for every closed set KKK with A⊆KA\subseteq KA⊆K we have A‾⊆K\overline{A}\subseteq KA⊆K.

Corollary 4.47: Let XXX be a metric space or a topological space, and let A⊆XA\subseteq XA⊆X.

  1. (Ao)o=Ao(A^o)^o=A^o(Ao)o=Ao and A‾‾=A‾\overline{\overline{A}}=\overline{A}A=A
  2. AAA is open if and only if A=AoA=A^oA=Ao
  3. AAA is closed if and only if A=A‾A=\overline{A}A=A

Interior Points, Limit Points and Boundary Points

Let XXX be a metric space and let A⊆XA\subseteq XA⊆X.

  • An interior point of AAA is a point a∈Aa\in Aa∈A such that for some r>0r>0r>0 we have B(a,r)⊆AB(a,r)\subseteq AB(a,r)⊆A.
  • A limit point of AAA is a point a∈Xa\in Xa∈X such that for every r>0r>0r>0 we have B∗(a,r)∩A≠∅B^*(a,r)\cap A\neq \emptyB∗(a,r)∩A​=∅.
    • The set of all limit points of AAA is denoted A′A'A′
  • An isolated point of AAA is a point a∈Aa\in Aa∈A which is not a limit point of AAA.
  • A boundary point of AAA is a point a∈Xa\in Xa∈X such that for every r>0r>0r>0 we have B(a,r)∩A≠∅B(a,r)\cap A\neq \emptyB(a,r)∩A​=∅ and B(a,r)∩Ac≠∅B(a,r)\cap A^c\neq \emptyB(a,r)∩Ac​=∅.
    • The boundary of AAA, denoted by ∂A\partial A∂A, is the set of all boundary points of AAA.

Theorem 4.49, Properties of Interior, Limit and Boundary Points: Let XXX be a metric space and let A⊆XA\subseteq XA⊆X:

  1. AoA^oAo is equal to the set of all interior points of AAA
  2. AAA is closed if and only if A′⊆AA'\subseteq AA′⊆A
  3. A‾=A∪A′\overline{A}=A\cup A'A=A∪A′
  4. ∂A=A‾\Ao\partial A = \overline{A}\backslash A^o∂A=A\Ao

Proof Sketch:

  • To prove Part 2, we need to show that AAA is closed ⟺(a∈A′⟹a∈A)\Longleftrightarrow (a\in A' \Longrightarrow a\in A)⟺(a∈A′⟹a∈A).
  • To prove Part 3, we shall prove that A∪A′A\cup A'A∪A′ is the smallest closed set wich contains AAA. We first show that A∪A′A\cup A'A∪A′ is closed. Let a∈(A∪A′)ca\in (A\cup A')^ca∈(A∪A′)c, we can show that ∃r>0\exists r>0∃r>0 such that B(a,r)∩A=∅B(a,r)\cap A = \emptyB(a,r)∩A=∅ and B(a,r)∩A′=∅B(a,r)\cap A' = \emptyB(a,r)∩A′=∅. It follows that (A∪A′)c(A\cup A')^c(A∪A′)c is open. It remains to show that for every closed set K⊆XK \subseteq XK⊆X with A⊆KA\subseteq KA⊆K, we have A∪A′⊆KA\cup A'\subseteq KA∪A′⊆K. Note that A⊆K⟹A′⊆K′A\subseteq K \Longrightarrow A'\subseteq K'A⊆K⟹A′⊆K′, and since KKK is closed by Part 2 we have K′⊆KK'\subseteq KK′⊆K. Hence we have A∪A′⊆KA\cup A'\subseteq KA∪A′⊆K as required. □\square□

Open and Closed Sets in Subspaces

Let XXX be a metric space and let P⊆XP\subseteq XP⊆X. Note that PPP is also a metric space using the restriction of the metric used in XXX. For a∈Pa\in Pa∈P and 0<r∈R0<r\in\mathbb{R}0<r∈R, note that the open and closed balls in PPP centered at aaa and of radius rrr are related to the open and closed balls in XXX by

BP(a,r)={x∈P:d(x,a)<r}=BX(a,r)∩PB‾P(a,r)={x∈P:d(x,a)≤r}=B‾X(a,r)∩P\begin{aligned} B_P(a,r) &=\{x\in P: d(x,a)<r\} = B_X(a,r)\cap P\\ \overline{B}_P(a,r) &=\{x\in P:d(x,a)\le r\}=\overline{B}_X(a,r)\cap P \end{aligned}BP​(a,r)BP​(a,r)​={x∈P:d(x,a)<r}=BX​(a,r)∩P={x∈P:d(x,a)≤r}=BX​(a,r)∩P​

Theorem 4.51: Let XXX be a metric space and let A⊆P⊆XA\subseteq P\subseteq XA⊆P⊆X.

  1. AAA is open in PPP if and only if there exists an open set U⊆XU\subseteq XU⊆X such that A=U∩PA=U\cap PA=U∩P.
  2. AAA is closed in PPP if and only if there exists a closed set K⊆XK\subseteq XK⊆X such that A=K∩PA=K\cap PA=K∩P.

Proof Sketch for Part 1:

  • (⇒)(\Rightarrow)(⇒): Let U=⋃a∈ABX(a,ra)\displaystyle U=\bigcup_{a\in A} B_X(a, r_a)U=a∈A⋃​BX​(a,ra​) where BP(a,ra)⊆AB_P(a,r_a)\subseteq ABP​(a,ra​)⊆A. We need to show that A⊆U∩PA\subseteq U\cap PA⊆U∩P and A⊇U∩PA\supseteq U\cap PA⊇U∩P.
  • (⇐)(\Leftarrow)(⇐): Let A=U∩PA=U\cap PA=U∩P with UUU open in XXX. Show that a∈A⟹BP(a,r)⊆Aa\in A\Longrightarrow B_P(a,r)\subseteq Aa∈A⟹BP​(a,r)⊆A where r>0r>0r>0 and BX(a,r)⊆UB_X(a,r)\subseteq UBX​(a,r)⊆U. □\square□

Subspace Topology: Let XXX be a topological space and let P⊆XP\subseteq XP⊆X. We can use the topology on XXX to define a topology on PPP. Given a set A⊆PA\subseteq PA⊆P, we define AAA to be open in PPP when A=U∩PA=U\cap PA=U∩P for some open set U⊆XU\subseteq XU⊆X. The resulting topology on PPP is called the subspace topology.

Limits and Continuity in Metric Spaces

Limits of Sequences in Metric Spaces

Boundedness of Sequence: Let (xn)n≥p(x_n)_{n\ge p}(xn​)n≥p​ be a sequence in a metric space XXX. We say that the sequence (xn)n≥p(x_n)_{n\ge p}(xn​)n≥p​ is bounded when the set {xn}n≥p\{x_n\}_{n\ge p}{xn​}n≥p​ is bounded, that is when there exists a∈Xa\in Xa∈X and r>0r>0r>0 such that xn∈B(a,r) ∀n≥px_n\in B(a,r)\ \forall n\ge pxn​∈B(a,r) ∀n≥p.

Convergence of Sequence: For a∈Xa\in Xa∈X we say that the sequence (xn)n≥p(x_n)_{n\ge p}(xn​)n≥p​ converges to aaa, or that the limit of xnx_nxn​ is equal to aaa, and we write lim⁡n→∞xn=a\displaystyle \lim_{n\rightarrow \infty} x_n=an→∞lim​xn​=a when ∀ϵ>0,∃m∈Z≥p\forall \epsilon >0,\exists m\in \mathbb{Z}_{\ge p}∀ϵ>0,∃m∈Z≥p​ such that any Z≥p∋n≥m⟹d(xn,a)<ϵ\mathbb{Z}_{\ge p}\ni n\ge m\Longrightarrow d(x_n, a)<\epsilonZ≥p​∋n≥m⟹d(xn​,a)<ϵ.

We say that the sequence converges in XXX when it converges to some point a∈Xa\in Xa∈X, and otherwise we say that (xn)n≥p(x_n)_{n\ge p}(xn​)n≥p​ diverges in XXX.

Theorem 5.2, Basic Properties of Limits of Sequences: Let (xn)n≥p(x_n)_{n\ge p}(xn​)n≥p​ be a sequence in a metric space XXX, and let a∈Xa\in Xa∈X.

  1. If (xn)n≥p(x_n)_{n\ge p}(xn​)n≥p​ converges then its limit is unique.
  2. If q≥pq\ge pq≥p and yn=xny_n = x_nyn​=xn​ for all n≥qn\ge qn≥q, then (xn)n≥p(x_n)_{n\ge p}(xn​)n≥p​ converges if and only if (yn)n≥q(y_n)_{n\ge q}(yn​)n≥q​ converges and in this case lim⁡n→∞yn=lim⁡n→∞xn\displaystyle \lim_{n\rightarrow\infty} y_n = \lim_{n\rightarrow \infty} x_nn→∞lim​yn​=n→∞lim​xn​.
  3. If (xnk)k≥q(x_{n_k})_{k\ge q}(xnk​​)k≥q​ is a subsequence of (xn)n≥p(x_n)_{n\ge p}(xn​)n≥p​, and lim⁡n→∞xn=a\displaystyle \lim_{n\rightarrow \infty} x_n=an→∞lim​xn​=a, then lim⁡k→∞xnk=a\displaystyle \lim_{k\rightarrow \infty} x_{n_k}=ak→∞lim​xnk​​=a.
  4. If (xn)n≥p(x_n)_{n\ge p}(xn​)n≥p​ converges then it is bounded.
  5. We have lim⁡n→∞xn=a\displaystyle \lim_{n\rightarrow \infty} x_n = an→∞lim​xn​=a in XXX if and only if lim⁡n→∞d(xn,a)=0\displaystyle \lim_{n\rightarrow \infty} d(x_n,a)=0n→∞lim​d(xn​,a)=0 in R\mathbb{R}R.

Note that because of Part 2 of Theorem 5.2, the initial index of a sequence (xn)(x_n)(xn​) does not effect whether or not the sequence converges, and it does not affect the limit. For this reason we often we often omit the initial index and write (xn)(x_n)(xn​).

Theorem 5.4, Components of Sequences in Rm\mathbb{R}^mRm: Let (xn)n≥1(x_n)_{n\ge 1}(xn​)n≥1​ be a sequence in Rm\mathbb{R}^mRm, say xn=(xn,1,xn,2,…,xn,m)∈Rmx_n=(x_{n,1}, x_{n,2},\dots, x_{n,m})\in \mathbb{R}^mxn​=(xn,1​,xn,2​,…,xn,m​)∈Rm, and let a=(a1,a2,…,am)∈Rma=(a_1,a_2,\dots, a_m)\in \mathbb{R}^ma=(a1​,a2​,…,am​)∈Rm. Then using any of the metrics d1,d2,d∞d_1, d_2, d_\inftyd1​,d2​,d∞​ in Rm\mathbb{R}^mRm, we have lim⁡n→∞xn=a\displaystyle \lim_{n\rightarrow \infty} x_n = an→∞lim​xn​=a in Rm\mathbb{R}^mRm if and only if lim⁡n→∞xn,k=ak\displaystyle \lim_{n\rightarrow \infty} x_{n,k}=a_kn→∞lim​xn,k​=ak​ for all indices k∈[1,m]k\in [1,m]k∈[1,m].

Note: When (xn)n≥1(x_n)_{n\ge 1}(xn​)n≥1​ is a sequence in R∞,ℓ1,ℓ2,ℓ∞\mathbb{R}^\infty, \ell_1, \ell_2, \ell_\inftyR∞,ℓ1​,ℓ2​,ℓ∞​, each term xnx_nxn​ is itself a sequence (so that (xn)(x_n)(xn​) is a sequence of sequences) and we can write $x_n=(x_{n,k})_{k\ge 1}, e.g. we have sequences x1=(x1,1,x1,2,… ),x2=(x2,1,x2,2,x2,3,… )x_1=(x_{1,1}, x_{1,2},\dots), x_2=(x_{2,1}, x_{2,2}, x_{2,3},\dots)x1​=(x1,1​,x1,2​,…),x2​=(x2,1​,x2,2​,x2,3​,…) and so on.

Theorem 5.6, Components of Sequences in ℓp\ell_pℓp​: Let p=1,2,∞p=1,2,\inftyp=1,2,∞. Let (xn)n≥1(x_n)_{n\ge 1}(xn​)n≥1​ be a sequence ℓp\ell_pℓp​, say that xn=(xn,k)k≥1∈ℓpx_n=(x_{n,k})_{k\ge 1}\in \ell_pxn​=(xn,k​)k≥1​∈ℓp​, and let a=(ak)k≥1∈ℓpa=(a_k)_{k\ge 1} \in \ell_pa=(ak​)k≥1​∈ℓp​. If lim⁡n→∞xn=a\displaystyle \lim_{n\rightarrow\infty} x_n = an→∞lim​xn​=a in ℓp\ell_pℓp​, then lim⁡n→∞xn,k=ak\displaystyle \lim_{n\rightarrow \infty} x_{n,k} = a_kn→∞lim​xn,k​=ak​ in R\mathbb{R}R for all k∈Z+k\in \mathbb{Z}^+k∈Z+.

Note: Unlike the case in Rm\mathbb{R}^mRm, in the infinite-dimensional spaces ℓp\ell_pℓp​, when xn,k→akx_{n,k}\rightarrow a_kxn,k​→ak​ in R\mathbb{R}R for all indices kkk, it does not necessarily follow that xn→ax_n\rightarrow axn​→a in ℓp\ell_pℓp​. For example, when xn=enx_n=e_nxn​=en​ (the nnnth standard basis vector in R∞\mathbb{R}^\inftyR∞) we have lim⁡n→∞xn,k=0\displaystyle \lim_{n\rightarrow \infty} x_{n,k} = 0n→∞lim​xn,k​=0 but lim⁡n→∞xn≠0\displaystyle \lim_{n\rightarrow \infty} x_n \neq 0n→∞lim​xn​​=0 in ℓp\ell_pℓp​.

Exercise: For each n∈Z+n\in \mathbb{Z}^+n∈Z+, let xn∈R∞x_n\in \mathbb{R}^\inftyxn​∈R∞ be the sequence given by xn=1n∑k=1nek\displaystyle x_n=\frac{1}{n} \sum_{k=1}^n e_kxn​=n1​k=1∑n​ek​, that is by xn=(xn,k)k≥1=(1n,1n,…,1n,0,0,0,… )x_n=(x_{n,k})_{k\ge 1} = \left( \frac{1}{n}, \frac{1}{n}, \dots, \frac{1}{n}, 0,0,0,\dots \right)xn​=(xn,k​)k≥1​=(n1​,n1​,…,n1​,0,0,0,…) with nnn non-zero terms. Theorem 5.11, Limits in B[a,b]\mathcal{B}[a,b]B[a,b] and Uniform Convergence: Let (fn)n≥1(f_n)_{n\ge 1}(fn​)n≥1​ be a sequence in B[a,b]\mathcal{B}[a,b]B[a,b], and let g∈B[a,b]g\in \mathcal{B}[a,b]g∈B[a,b]. Then fn→gf_n\rightarrow gfn​→g in (B[a,b],d∞)\left( \mathcal{B}[a,b], d_\infty \right)(B[a,b],d∞​) if and only if fn→gf_n\rightarrow gfn​→g uniformly on [a,b][a,b][a,b].

Remark: We discussed the pointwise convergence and uniform convergence of sequences of functions. We now have several different notions of convergence for sequences of functions. Theorem 5.11 shows that convergence in metric space B[a,b]\mathcal{B}[a,b]B[a,b] (hence also in C[a,b]\mathcal{C}[a,b]C[a,b]) using the supremum metric d∞d_\inftyd∞​ is the same thing as uniform convergence.

One might ask whether convergence in C[a,b]\mathbb{C}[a,b]C[a,b] using the metrics d1,d2d_1, d_2d1​,d2​ implies or is implied by pointwise convergence. The answer is no, as the following exercises illustrate.

Limits and Closed Sets

Theorem 5.16, The Sequential Characterization of Limit Points and Closed Sets: Let XXX be a metric space, let a∈Xa\in Xa∈X and let A⊆XA\subseteq XA⊆X.

  1. a∈A′a\in A'a∈A′ if and only if there exists a sequence (xn)(x_n)(xn​) in A\{a}A\backslash \{a\}A\{a} with lim⁡n→∞xn=a\displaystyle \lim_{n\rightarrow \infty} x_n=an→∞lim​xn​=a in XXX.
  2. a∈A‾a\in \overline{A}a∈A if and only if there exists a sequence (xn)(x_n)(xn​) in AAA with lim⁡n→∞xn=a\displaystyle \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} x_n = an→∞lim​xn​=a in XXX.
  3. AAA is closed in XXX if and only if for every sequence (xn)(x_n)(xn​) in AAA which converges in XXX, we have lim⁡n→∞xn∈A\displaystyle \lim_{n\rightarrow \infty} x_n\in An→∞lim​xn​∈A

Proof Sketch for Part 3:

  • (⇒)(\Rightarrow)(⇒): use contradiction
  • (⇐)(\Leftarrow)(⇐): show that a∈A′⟹a∈Aa\in A'\Longrightarrow a\in Aa∈A′⟹a∈A. We have A′⊆AA'\subseteq AA′⊆A, so AAA is closed.

Example 5.17: Let UUU be a normed linear space, let a∈Ua\in Ua∈U and let r>0r>0r>0. Show that B(a,r)‾=B‾(a,r)\overline{B(a,r)}=\overline{B}(a,r)B(a,r)​=B(a,r), so the closed ball is equal to the closure of the open ball.

Let b∈B‾(a,r)b\in \overline{B}(a,r)b∈B(a,r), construct a sequence (xn)(x_n)(xn​) in B(a,r)B(a,r)B(a,r) converging at bbb. Then by Theorem 5.16 part 2,we have b∈B(a,r)‾b\in \overline{B(a,r)}b∈B(a,r)​. □\square□

It might have seemed intuitively obvious that B(a,r)‾=B‾(a,r)\overline{B(a,r)}=\overline{B}(a,r)B(a,r)​=B(a,r), but this is not true in all metric spaces. We define the following sets of functions:

Limits of Functions and Continuity in Metric Spaces

Convergence of Function: Let (X,dX)(X, d_X)(X,dX​) and (Y,dY)(Y, d_Y)(Y,dY​) be metric spaces. Let A⊆XA\subseteq XA⊆X, let f:A→Yf:A\rightarrow Yf:A→Y, let a∈A′a\in A'a∈A′, and let b∈Yb\in Yb∈Y. We say that the limit of f(x)f(x)f(x) as xxx tends to aaa is equal to bbb, and we write lim⁡x→af(x)=b\displaystyle \lim_{x\rightarrow a} f(x)=bx→alim​f(x)=b, when ∀ϵ>0,∃δ\forall \epsilon>0, \exists \delta∀ϵ>0,∃δ such that any x∈Ax\in Ax∈A with 0<dX(x,a)<δ⟹dY(f(x),b)<δ0<d_X(x,a)<\delta \Longrightarrow d_Y (f(x),b)<\delta0<dX​(x,a)<δ⟹dY​(f(x),b)<δ.

Theorem 5.24, Sequential Characterization of Limits: Let X,YX,YX,Y be metric spaces, let A⊆XA\subseteq XA⊆X, let f:A→Yf:A\rightarrow Yf:A→Y, let a∈A′a\in A'a∈A′ and let b∈Yb\in Yb∈Y. Then lim⁡x→af(x)=b\displaystyle \lim_{x\rightarrow a}f(x)=bx→alim​f(x)=b if and only if for every sequence (xn)(x_n)(xn​) in A\{a}A\backslash \{a\}A\{a} with xn→ax_n\rightarrow axn​→a we have lim⁡n→∞f(xn)=b\displaystyle \lim_{n\rightarrow \infty} f(x_n)=bn→∞lim​f(xn​)=b

Proof Sketch (⇐)(\Leftarrow)(⇐): suppose that lim⁡x→af(x)≠b\displaystyle \lim_{x\rightarrow a} f(x)\neq bx→alim​f(x)​=b. Construct a sequence (xn)(x_n)(xn​) in A\{a}A\backslash \{a\}A\{a} such that xn→ax_n\rightarrow axn​→a and lim⁡n→∞f(xn)≠b\displaystyle \lim_{n\rightarrow \infty}f(x_n)\neq bn→∞lim​f(xn​)​=b.

Continuity of Functions: Let (X,dX)(X, d_X)(X,dX​) and (Y,dY)(Y, d_Y)(Y,dY​) be metric spaces, and let f:X→Yf:X\rightarrow Yf:X→Y.

  • For a∈Xa\in Xa∈X, we say that fff is continuous at aaa when ∀ϵ>0,∃δ>0\forall \epsilon>0, \exists \delta >0∀ϵ>0,∃δ>0 such that any x∈Xx\in Xx∈X with dX(x,a)<δ⟹dY(f(x),f(a))<ϵd_X(x,a)<\delta \Longrightarrow d_Y(f(x),f(a))<\epsilondX​(x,a)<δ⟹dY​(f(x),f(a))<ϵ.
  • We say that fff is uniformly continuous on XXX when ∀ϵ>0,∃δ>0\forall \epsilon>0,\exists \delta > 0∀ϵ>0,∃δ>0 such that any x,y∈Xx,y\in Xx,y∈X with dX(x,y)<δ⟹dY(f(x),f(y))<ϵd_X(x,y)< \delta \Longrightarrow d_Y(f(x), f(y))<\epsilondX​(x,y)<δ⟹dY​(f(x),f(y))<ϵ.
  • We say that fff is Lipschitz continuous on XXX when there is a constant ℓ≥0\ell \ge 0ℓ≥0, called a Lipschitz constant for fff, such that ∀x,y∈X\forall x,y\in X∀x,y∈X, we have d(f(x),f(y))≤ℓ⋅d(x,y)d(f(x), f(y))\le \ell \cdot d(x,y)d(f(x),f(y))≤ℓ⋅d(x,y). Note that if fff is Lipschitz continuous then fff is also uniformly continuous, indeed we can take δ=ϵ/ℓ\delta = \epsilon/\ellδ=ϵ/ℓ in the definition of uniform continuity.
  • A bijective map f:X→Yf:X\rightarrow Yf:X→Y such that both fff and f−1f^{-1}f−1 are continuous is called a homeomorphism (not a typo, see Homeomorphism!)

Use Limit to Test Continuity: Let X,YX,YX,Y be metric spaces and let a∈Xa\in Xa∈X. If aaa is a limit point of XXX then fff is continuous at aaa if and only if lim⁡x→af(x)=f(a)\displaystyle \lim_{x\rightarrow a}f(x)=f(a)x→alim​f(x)=f(a). If aaa is an isolated point of XXX then fff is necessarily continuous at aaa, vacuously.

Theorem 5.27, Sequential Characterization of Continuity: Let X,YX,YX,Y be metric spaces using metrics dX,dYd_X, d_YdX​,dY​, let f:X→Yf:X\rightarrow Yf:X→Y, and let a∈Xa\in Xa∈X. Then fff is continuous at aaa if and only if for every sequence (xn)(x_n)(xn​) in XXX with xn→ax_n\rightarrow axn​→a we have lim⁡n→∞f(xn)=f(a)\displaystyle \lim_{n\rightarrow \infty} f(x_n) = f(a)n→∞lim​f(xn​)=f(a).

Exercise 5.28: Let X,Y,ZX,Y,ZX,Y,Z be metric spaces, let f:X→Yf:X\rightarrow Yf:X→Y, let g:Y→Zg:Y\rightarrow Zg:Y→Z. Show that if fff is continuous at the point a∈Xa\in Xa∈X and ggg is continuous at the point f(a)∈Yf(a)\in Yf(a)∈Y then the composite function g∘fg\circ fg∘f is continuous at aaa.

Theorem 5.29, The Topological Characterization of Continuity: Let X,YX,YX,Y be metric spaces and let f:X→Yf:X\rightarrow Yf:X→Y. Then

  1. fff is continuous on XXX if and only if f−1(V)f^{-1}(V)f−1(V) is open in XXX for every open set V⊆YV\subseteq YV⊆Y.
  2. fff is continuous on XXX if and only if f−1(C)f^{-1}(C)f−1(C) is closed for every closed set CCC in YYY.

Continuity and Homeomorphism on Topological Spaces: Let X,YX,YX,Y be topological spaces and let f:X→Yf:X\rightarrow Yf:X→Y. We say that fff is continuous on XXX when f−1f^{-1}f−1(V)$ is open in XXX for every open set V⊆YV\subseteq YV⊆Y. A bijective map f:X→Yf:X\rightarrow Yf:X→Y such that both fff and f−1f^{-1}f−1 are continuous is called a homeomorphism.

Theorem 5.31, Composition of Continuous Functions: Let X,Y,ZX,Y,ZX,Y,Z be metric spaces or topological spaces, let f:X→Yf:X\rightarrow Yf:X→Y and let g:Y→Zg:Y\rightarrow Zg:Y→Z. If f,gf,gf,g are continuous then the composite function g∘f:X→Zg\circ f: X\rightarrow Zg∘f:X→Z is continuous.

Example 5.32: Let A={(x,y)∈R2:y<x2}A=\{(x,y)\in \mathbb{R}^2: y<x^2 \}A={(x,y)∈R2:y<x2}, show that AAA is open in R2\mathbb{R}^2R2.

Example 5.33: Recall that every set U⊆C[a,b]U\subseteq \mathcal{C}[a,b]U⊆C[a,b] which is open using the metric d1d_1d1​ is also open using the metric d∞d_\inftyd∞​, but not vice versa. It follows from Theorem 5.29 that the identity map I:C→C[a,b]I:C\rightarrow C[a,b]I:C→C[a,b] given by I(f)=fI(f)=fI(f)=f is continuous as a map from the metric space (C[a,b],d∞)(\mathcal{C}[a,b],d_\infty)(C[a,b],d∞​) to the metric space (C[a,b],d1)(\mathcal{C}[a,b], d_1)(C[a,b],d1​) but not vice versa.

Continuity of Linear Maps

If UUU and VVV are inner product spaces and L:U→VL:U\rightarrow VL:U→V is an inner product space isomorphism, then LLL and its inverse preserve distance so they are both continuous (we can take δ=ϵ\delta=\epsilonδ=ϵ in the definition of continuity).

If U,VU,VU,V are finite-dimensional inner product spaces with say dim⁡U=n\dim U=ndimU=n and dim⁡V=m\dim V = mdimV=m, and if ϕ:Rn→U\phi:\mathbb{R}^n\rightarrow Uϕ:Rn→U and ψ:Rm→V\psi:\mathbb{R}^m\rightarrow Vψ:Rm→V are inner product space isomorphisms obtained by choosing orthonormal bases for U,VU,VU,V. Then a map F:U→VF:U\rightarrow VF:U→V is continuous if and only if the composite map ψ−1Fϕ:Rn→Rm\psi^{-1}F\phi:\mathbb{R}^n\rightarrow \mathbb{R}^mψ−1Fϕ:Rn→Rm is continuous. In particular, if FFF is linear then FFF is continuous (since ψ−1Fϕ:Rn→Rm\psi^{-1} F \phi: \mathbb{R}^n\rightarrow \mathbb{R}^mψ−1Fϕ:Rn→Rm is linear, hence continuous).

Theorem 5.35: Let U,VU,VU,V be normed linear spaces and let F:U→VF:U\rightarrow VF:U→V be linear map. Then the following are equivalent:

  1. FFF is Lipschitz continuous on UUU
  2. FFF is continuous at some point a∈Ua\in Ua∈U
  3. FFF is continuous at 000
  4. F(B‾(0,1))F(\overline{B}(0,1))F(B(0,1)) is bounded

In this case, if m≥0m\ge 0m≥0 with F(B‾(0,1))⊆B(0,m)F(\overline{B}(0,1))\subseteq B(0,m)F(B(0,1))⊆B(0,m), then mmm is a Lipschitz constant for FFF.

Theorem 5.38: Let UUU be an nnn-dimensional normed linear space over R\mathbb{R}R. Let {u1,…,un}\{u_1,\dots, u_n\}{u1​,…,un​} be any basis for UUU and let ϕ:Rn→U\phi:\mathbb{R}^n\rightarrow Uϕ:Rn→U be the associated vector space isomorphism given by ϕ(t)=∑k=1ntkuk\displaystyle \phi(t)=\sum_{k=1}^n t_k u_kϕ(t)=k=1∑n​tk​uk​. Then both ϕ\phiϕ and ϕ−1\phi^{-1}ϕ−1 are Lipschitz continuous.

Corollary 5.39: When U,VU,VU,V are finite-dimensional normed linear spaces, every linear map F:U→VF:U\rightarrow VF:U→V is Lipschitz continuous.

Corollary 5.40: Any two norms on a finite-dimensional vector space UUU induce the same topology on UUU.

Corollary 5.41: Let UUU be a finite-dimensional vector space. Let ∥∥1\| \|_1∥∥1​ and ∥∥2\|\|_2∥∥2​ be two norms on UUU inducing two metric d1,d2d_1, d_2d1​,d2​ on UUU. Let (xn)n≥1(x_n)_{n\ge 1}(xn​)n≥1​ be a sequence in UUU, and let a∈Ua\in Ua∈U. Then xn→ax_n\rightarrow axn​→a in (U,d1)(U,d_1)(U,d1​) if and only if xn→ax_n\rightarrow axn​→a in (U,d2)(U, d_2)(U,d2​).

Completeness and Compactness

Completeness

Cauchy Sequence: A sequence (xk)k≥p(x_k)_{k\ge p}(xk​)k≥p​ in a metric space XXX is called Cauchy when ∀ϵ>0,∃m∈Z≥p\forall \epsilon > 0, \exists m\in \mathbb{Z}_{\ge p}∀ϵ>0,∃m∈Z≥p​ such that any $k,l\in \mathbb{Z}_{\ge p} with k,l≥m⟹d(xk,xl)<ϵk,l\ge m \Longrightarrow d(x_k, x_l)<\epsilonk,l≥m⟹d(xk​,xl​)<ϵ.

  • A metric space XXX is called complete when every Cauchy sequence in XXX converges in XXX.
  • A complete inner product space is called a Hilbert space
  • A complete normed linear space is called a Banach space

R\mathbb{R}R is complete by the Cauchy Criterion for Convergence (Theorem 1.25).

Theorem 6.3: Let XXX be a metric space

  1. Every Cauchy sequence in XXX is bounded
  2. Every convergent sequence in XXX is Cauchy
  3. If some subsequence of a Cauchy sequence (xn)(x_n)(xn​) converges, then (xn)(x_n)(xn​) converges.

Theorem 6.4: Let XXX be a complete metric space and let A⊆XA\subseteq XA⊆X. Then AAA is complete if and only if AAA is closed in XXX.

The Completeness of Rm\mathbb{R}^mRm

Theorem 6.5, Bolzano-Weierstrass Theorem: Every bounded sequence in Rm\mathbb{R}^mRm has a convergent subsequence (using the standard metric in Rm\mathbb{R}^mRm).

Theorem 6.6, The Completeness of Rm\mathbb{R}^mRm: For every sequence in Rm\mathbb{R}^mRm, the sequence converges if and only if it is Cauchy (where we are using the standard metric in Rm\mathbb{R}^mRm).

Theorem 6.7: Every finite-dimensional normed linear space is complete.

Corollary 6.8: The metric spaces (Rm,d1),(Rm,d2),(Rm,d∞)(\mathbb{R}^m, d_1), (\mathbb{R}^m, d_2), (\mathbb{R}^m, d_\infty)(Rm,d1​),(Rm,d2​),(Rm,d∞​) are all complete.

Corollary 6.9: Let UUU be a normed linear space and let A⊆UA\subseteq UA⊆U. Then AAA is complete if and only if AAA is closed in UUU.

The Completeness of Spaces of Sequences and Spaces of Functions

Theorem 6.10: The metric spaces (ℓ1,d1),(ℓ2,d2),(ℓ∞,d∞)(\ell_1, d_1), (\ell_2, d_2), (\ell_\infty , d_\infty)(ℓ1​,d1​),(ℓ2​,d2​),(ℓ∞​,d∞​) are all complete.

Exercise 6.11: After showing that (ℓ∞,d∞)(\ell_\infty, d_\infty)(ℓ∞​,d∞​) is complete, show that (ℓ1,d∞)(\ell_1, d_\infty)(ℓ1​,d∞​) and (ℓ2,d∞)(\ell_2, d_\infty)(ℓ2​,d∞​) are not closed in (ℓ∞,d∞)(\ell_\infty, d_\infty)(ℓ∞​,d∞​) and so they are not complete.

Sets of Functions on metric space XXX, define

B(X)=B(X,R)={f:X→R:f is bounded}C(X)=C(X,R)={f:X→R:f is continuous}Cb(X)=Cb(X,R)={f:X→R:f is bounded and continuous}\begin{aligned} \mathcal{B}(X)&=\mathcal{B}(X,\mathbb{R})=\{f:X\rightarrow \mathbb{R}:f\textrm{ is bounded}\}\\ \mathcal{C}(X)&=\mathcal{C}(X,\mathbb{R})=\{f:X\rightarrow \mathbb{R}:f\textrm{ is continuous}\}\\ \mathcal{C}_b(X)&=\mathcal{C}_b(X,\mathbb{R})=\{f:X\rightarrow \mathbb{R}: f\textrm{ is bounded and continuous}\} \end{aligned}B(X)C(X)Cb​(X)​=B(X,R)={f:X→R:f is bounded}=C(X,R)={f:X→R:f is continuous}=Cb​(X,R)={f:X→R:f is bounded and continuous}​

Note that B(X)\mathcal{B}(X)B(X) is a normed linear space using the supremum norm given by ∥f∥∞=sup⁡x∈X∣f(x)∣\displaystyle \|f\|_\infty = \sup_{x\in X}|f(x)|∥f∥∞​=x∈Xsup​∣f(x)∣, and a metric space under the supremum metric given by d∞(f,g)=sup⁡x∈X∣f(x)−g(x)∣\displaystyle d_\infty(f,g)=\sup_{x\in X} |f(x)-g(x)|d∞​(f,g)=x∈Xsup​∣f(x)−g(x)∣.

Uniform Convergence of Sequence of Functions: For a sequence of (fn)(f_n)(fn​) of functions fn:X→Rf_n:X\rightarrow \mathbb{R}fn​:X→R and a function g:X→Rg:X\rightarrow \mathbb{R}g:X→R, we say that (fn)(f_n)(fn​) converges uniformly to ggg on XXX and write fn→gf_n\rightarrow gfn​→g uniformly on XXX when ∀ϵ>0,∃m∈Z+\forall \epsilon >0, \exists m\in \mathbb{Z}^+∀ϵ>0,∃m∈Z+ such that any n∈Z+n\in \mathbb{Z}^+n∈Z+ with n≥m⟹∣fn(x)−g(x)∣<ϵ,∀x∈Xn\ge m \Longrightarrow |f_n(x)-g(x)|<\epsilon, \forall x\in Xn≥m⟹∣fn​(x)−g(x)∣<ϵ,∀x∈X.

Note: for a sequence (fn)∈B(X)(f_n)\in \mathcal{B}(X)(fn​)∈B(X) and for g∈B(X)g\in \mathcal{B}(X)g∈B(X), note that ∣fn(x)−g∣<ϵ|f_n(x)-g|<\epsilon∣fn​(x)−g∣<ϵ for every x∈Xx\in Xx∈X if and only if ∥fn−g∥∞<ϵ\|f_n-g\|_{\infty}<\epsilon∥fn​−g∥∞​<ϵ. It follows that fn→gf_n\rightarrow gfn​→g uniformly on XXX if and only if fn→gf_n\rightarrow gfn​→g in the metric space (B(X),d∞)(\mathcal{B}(X),d_\infty)(B(X),d∞​).

Theorem 6.15: Let XXX be a metric space. Then the metric spaces (B(X),d∞)(\mathcal{B}(X), d_\infty)(B(X),d∞​) and (Cb(X),d∞)(\mathcal{C}_b(X),d_\infty)(Cb​(X),d∞​) are complete.

Corollary 6.16: The metric space (C[a,b],d∞)(\mathcal{C}[a,b], d_\infty)(C[a,b],d∞​) is complete.

Exercise 6.17: Show that metric spaces (C[a,b],d1)(\mathcal{C}[a,b], d_1)(C[a,b],d1​) and (C[a,b],d2)(\mathcal{C}[a,b], d_2)(C[a,b],d2​) are not complete.

Compactness

Let XXX be a metric space (or a topological space) and let A⊆XA\subseteq XA⊆X.

  • An open cover for AAA in XXX is a set SSS of open sets in XXX such that A⊆⋃SA\subseteq \bigcup SA⊆⋃S.
  • A subcover of open cover SSS for AAA is a subset T⊆ST\subseteq ST⊆S such that A⊆⋃TA\subseteq \bigcup TA⊆⋃T.
  • We say that AAA is compact in XXX when every open cover for AAA has a finite subcover.

Theorem 6.19: Let A⊆X⊆YA\subseteq X\subseteq YA⊆X⊆Y where YYY is a metric space (or a topological space). Then AAA is compact in XXX if and only if AAA is compact in YYY.

Let A⊆XA\subseteq XA⊆X where XXX is a metric space or topological space. By the above theorem, AAA is compact in xxx if and only if AAA is compact in itself. For this reason, we do not usually say that AAA is compact in XXX, we simply say that AAA is compact.

Theorem 6.21: If metric space AAA is compact then AAA is closed and bounded.

Theorem 6.22: Let XXX be a metric space (or a topological space) and let A⊆XA\subseteq XA⊆X. If XXX is compact and AAA is closed in XXX, then AAA is compact.

Compactness in Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn

A closed bounded rectangle in Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn is a set of the form

R=[a1,b1]×[a2,b2]×⋯×[an,bn]={(x1,x2,…,xn)∈Rn:aj≤xj≤bj,∀j}\begin{aligned} R&=[a_1, b_1]\times [a_2, b_2]\times \cdots \times [a_n, b_n]\\ &=\{(x_1,x_2,\dots, x_n)\in \mathbb{R}^n:a_j\le x_j\le b_j, \forall j\} \end{aligned}R​=[a1​,b1​]×[a2​,b2​]×⋯×[an​,bn​]={(x1​,x2​,…,xn​)∈Rn:aj​≤xj​≤bj​,∀j}​

Theorem 6.24, Nested Rectangles: Let (Rk)k≥1(R_k)_{k\ge 1}(Rk​)k≥1​ be a sequence of closed bounded rectangles in Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn with R1⊇R2⊇R3⊇⋯R_1\supseteq R_2 \supseteq R_3\supseteq \cdotsR1​⊇R2​⊇R3​⊇⋯. Then

⋂k=1∞Rk≠∅\bigcap_{k=1}^\infty R_k\neq \empty k=1⋂∞​Rk​​=∅

Theorem 6.25, Compactness of Rectangles: Every closed bounded rectangles in Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn is compact (using the standard topology in Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn).

Theorem 6.26, Heine-Borel Theorem: Let A⊆RnA\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nA⊆Rn. Then AAA is compact if and only if AAA is closed and bounded (using the standard topology in Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn).

Compact Sets and Continuous Maps

Theorem 6.27: Let X,YX,YX,Y be metric spaces or topological spaces, and let f:X→Yf:X\rightarrow Yf:X→Y. If XXX is compact and fff is continuous, then f(X)f(X)f(X) is compact.

Note that continuous maps do not necessarily send closed set to closed sets. For example, the map f:R→Rf:\mathbb{R}\rightarrow \mathbb{R}f:R→R given by f(x)=2πtan⁡−1(x)f(x)=\frac{2}{\pi} \tan^{-1}(x)f(x)=π2​tan−1(x) sends the closed set R\mathbb{R}R homeomorphically to the open interval (−1,1)(-1, 1)(−1,1).

Theorem 6.29, Extreme Value Theorem: Let XXX be a compact metric space (or topological space) and let f:X→Rf:X\rightarrow \mathbb{R}f:X→R be continuous. Then there exists a,b∈Xa,b\in Xa,b∈X such that f(a)≤f(x)≤f(b)f(a)\le f(x)\le f(b)f(a)≤f(x)≤f(b) for all x∈Xx\in Xx∈X.

Theorem 6.30: Let X,YX,YX,Y be metric spaces or topological spaces with XXX compact. Let f:X→Yf:X\rightarrow Yf:X→Y be continuous and bijective. Then fff is a homeomorphism.

Note the requirement that XXX is compact is necessary. For example, if XXX is the internal X=[0,2π)X=[0,2\pi)X=[0,2π) and YYY is the unit circle Y={z∈C:∥z∥=1}Y=\{z\in \mathbb{C}:\|z\|=1\}Y={z∈C:∥z∥=1}, then the map f:X→Yf:X\rightarrow Yf:X→Y given by f(t)=eitf(t)=e^{it}f(t)=eit is continuous and bijective, but the inverse map is not continuous at 1.

Theorem 6.32: Let X,YX,YX,Y be metric spaces with XXX compact and let f:X→Yf:X\rightarrow Yf:X→Y be continuous. Then fff is uniformly continuous.

Theorem 6.33: Let X,YX,YX,Y be metric spaces or topological spaces, and let f:X→Yf:X\rightarrow Yf:X→Y be a homeomorphism (which means that fff is bijective and both f,f−1f,f^{-1}f,f−1 are continuous). Then for every set A⊆XA\subseteq XA⊆X, AAA is compact in XXX if and only if f(A)f(A)f(A) is compact in YYY.

Note that when X,YX,YX,Y are metric spaces and f:X→Yf:X\rightarrow Yf:X→Y is a homeomorphism and A⊆XA\subseteq XA⊆X, it is not always the case that for every A⊆XA\subseteq XA⊆X, AAA is complete if and only if f(A)f(A)f(A) is complete. For example, the map f:(−π2,π2)→Rf:\left( -\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2} \right)\rightarrow \mathbb{R}f:(−2π​,2π​)→R given by f(x)=tan⁡xf(x)=\tan xf(x)=tanx is a homeomorphism, but (−π2,π2)\left( -\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2} \right)(−2π​,2π​) is not complete whereas R\mathbb{R}R is complete.

Theorem 6.35: Let AAA be a subset of a finite-dimensional normed linear space UUU. Then AAA is compact if and only if AAA is closed and bounded.

Some Characterizations of Compactness

Total Boundedness: Let XXX be a metric space. We say that XXX is totally bounded when ∀ϵ>0\forall \epsilon > 0∀ϵ>0 there exists a finite subset {a1,a2,…,an}⊆X\{a_1, a_2, \dots, a_n\}\subseteq X{a1​,a2​,…,an​}⊆X such that X=⋃i=1nB(ai,ϵ)X=\bigcup_{i=1}^n B(a_i, \epsilon)X=⋃i=1n​B(ai​,ϵ).

We say that XXX has the finite intersection property on closed sets when for every set TTT of closed sets in XXX, if every finite subset of TTT has non-empty intersection, then TTT has non-empty intersection.

Theorem 6.38: Let XXX be a metric space. Then the following are equivalent.

  1. XXX is compact
  2. XXX has the finite intersection property on closed sets
  3. Every sequence (xn)(x_n)(xn​) in XXX has a convergent subsequence
  4. Every infinite subset A⊆XA\subseteq XA⊆X has a limit point
  5. XXX is complete and totally bounded.

Example: Show that in the metric space (C[0,1],d∞)(\mathcal{C}[0,1], d_\infty)(C[0,1],d∞​), the closed unit ball B‾(0,1)\overline{B}(0,1)B(0,1) is not compact.
